timeline.message:
Add more filter rates to BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReaders

This commit adds more filter rates to BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReader
in order to test SliceDirectSelectiveStreamReader.readWithFilter().
It also changes the reporting unit from second to millisecond since
lots of operations only takes 1x ms per op now.

Add more filter rates to BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReaders

This commit adds more filter rates to BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReader
in order to test SliceDirectSelectiveStreamReader.readWithFilter().
It also changes the reporting unit from second to millisecond since
lots of operations only takes 1x ms per op now.

timeline.author: sdruzkin

timeline.bodyText: lengthVectorIndex can be replaced with i
timeline.author: sdruzkin

timeline.bodyText: would be nice to wrap this comment
timeline.author: sdruzkin

timeline.message:
Add more filter rates to BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReaders

This commit adds more filter rates to BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReader
in order to test SliceDirectSelectiveStreamReader.readWithFilter().
It also changes the reporting unit from second to millisecond since
lots of operations only takes 1x ms per op now.

timeline.bodyText: offsets[0] is not initialized to 0 ? Though this may be safe, as java initializes the array values to 0.
timeline.author: arunthirupathi

replies.bodyText: offset[0] is always 0 in the reader as the position starts from 0.
replies.author: yingsu00

timeline.author: arunthirupathi

replies.bodyText: No. The positionCount comes from the batchSize in OrcSelectiveRecordReader and it starts with 1 and onwards. After each read, if output positionCount is 0, it will cause early termination of the StreamReader read loop in OrcSelectiveRecordReader.getNextPage()
replies.author: yingsu00

timeline.bodyText: Reading the comment and this line is little confusing. Can you please add comment on Why this is enabled only for unboundedVarchar ?
timeline.author: arunthirupathi

replies.author: yingsu00

timeline.bodyText: nit: you can mark this final and defer initialization. Java compiler will throw error, when it is not set in all paths.
timeline.author: arunthirupathi

timeline.bodyText: The other code path sets nulls array unconditionally, why is the nullsAllowed condition added here ?
timeline.author: arunthirupathi

replies.bodyText: Both readNoFilter and readWithFilter had this check. This is because the nulls vector was created when presentStream != null && nullsAllowed.
replies.author: yingsu00

timeline.bodyText:
positionCount must be greater than 0 here as the first line in the method calls
int totalPositionCount = positions[positionCount - 1] + 1;
timeline.author: arunthirupathi

replies.bodyText: Yes, you are right. I removed the positionCount > 0 check.
replies.author: yingsu00

timeline.bodyText: Isn't this case has maxLength as 0 ?
timeline.author: arunthirupathi

replies.bodyText: @arunthirupathi outputRequired == false doesn't mean the maxLength is 0. outputRequired means this column is one of the output columns. Some columns may not be output columns but still need to read because it has filters.
replies.author: yingsu00

timeline.message:
Add more filter rates to BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReaders

This commit adds more filter rates to BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReader
in order to test SliceDirectSelectiveStreamReader.readWithFilter().
It also changes the reporting unit from second to millisecond since
lots of operations only takes 1x ms per op now.

This commit adds more filter rates to BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReader
in order to test SliceDirectSelectiveStreamReader.readWithFilter().
It also changes the reporting unit from second to millisecond since
lots of operations only takes 1x ms per op now.

It also changes the reporting unit from second to millisecond since

Add more filter rates to BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReaders

This commit adds more filter rates to BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReader
in order to test SliceDirectSelectiveStreamReader.readWithFilter().
It also changes the reporting unit from second to millisecond since
lots of operations only takes 1x ms per op now.

Add more filter rates to BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReaders

This commit adds more filter rates to BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReader
in order to test SliceDirectSelectiveStreamReader.readWithFilter().
It also changes the reporting unit from second to millisecond since
lots of operations only takes 1x ms per op now.

Improve reading unbounded varchar with batch read mode

When the varchar column is unbounded, there's no need to truncate it.
This commit read the data in one shot then pack it for the selected
positions for suitable cases.

BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReaders shows improvements for almost all input
filter rates for both readNoFilter and readWithFilter except only one
case, where filter rate = 0.1 for readWithFilter. The
improvement ratio is up to 3.8x for readNoFilter, and 2.36x for
readWithFilter. In the following test results, filter rate means the
percentage of rows being filtered out when the readXXX() functions were
called. E.g. 0.1|-1 means the first column being read is with filter
and will eliminate 10% of rows, and when the second column is being
read, the positionCount will be 90% of totalPositionCount, and there is
no filter on the second column.

No nulls

After

Improve reading the lengthVector in SliceDirectSelectiveStreamReader

This commit uses a more CPU friendly API next() to read all lengths.

JMH benchmark when reading unbounded varchar for all rows:

Baseline
Benchmark                                      (withNulls)  Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReaders.readAllBlocks      PARTIAL  avgt    5  0.109 ± 0.018   s/op
BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReaders.readAllBlocks         NONE  avgt    5  0.102 ± 0.008   s/op

After
Benchmark                                      (withNulls)  Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReaders.readAllBlocks      PARTIAL  avgt    5  0.107 ± 0.015   s/op
BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReaders.readAllBlocks         NONE  avgt    5  0.084 ± 0.005   s/op

Add more filter rates to BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReaders

This commit adds more filter rates to BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReader
in order to test SliceDirectSelectiveStreamReader.readWithFilter().
It also changes the reporting unit from second to millisecond since
lots of operations only takes 1x ms per op now.

Add more filter rates to BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReaders

This commit adds more filter rates to BenchmarkSelectiveStreamReader
in order to test SliceDirectSelectiveStreamReader.readWithFilter().
It also changes the reporting unit from second to millisecond since
lots of operations only takes 1x ms per op now.
